section.title: Introduction
section.para: System daemons, cron jobs, &systemd; timers, and other applications can generate messages and send them to the &rootuser; user of the system. By default, each user account owns a local mailbox and will be notified about new mail messages upon login.

These messages can contain security-relevant reports and incidents that might require a quick response by the system administrator. To get notified about these messages in a timely fashion, it is strongly recommended to forward these mails to a dedicated remote e-mail account that is regularly checked.

section.title: Configure &rootuser; mail forwarding with &yast;
section.para: The following procedure describes how to configure mail forwarding for the &rootuser; user to a dedicated remote e-mail account.

procedure.para: To forward mail for the &rootuser; user, perform the following steps:

step.para: Choose Permanent as Connection type and proceed with Next.

Enter the address of the Outgoing mail server. If necessary, configure Authentication. It is strongly recommended to Enforce TLS encryption to prevent potentially sensitive system data from being sent unencrypted over the network. Proceed with Next.
Enter the e-mail address to Forward root's mail to and Finish the configuration.

important.title: Do not accept remote SMTP connections
important.para: Do not enable Accept remote SMTP connections, otherwise the local machine will act as a mail relay.

step.para: Send a message to test whether the mail forwarding works correctly:
Check the remote e-mail account for new messages. Your test message should arrive within minutes.

section.title: Troubleshooting
section.para: If the test message does not arrive, perform the following steps to analyze the problem.

listitem.para: Check if the postfix daemon is running with systemctl status postfix.service. If the service is down, the output includes additional information on the cause of the problem.

varlistentry.term: Has the test message been sent?

listitem.para: Use the mailq command to verify that the test message has been sent. Upon success, the queue should be empty.

varlistentry.term: Is the outgoing mail server resolved correctly?

listitem.para: Check that the system resolves the mail server of the remote e-mail account correctly. Run host -t mx &exampledomain; (where &exampledomain; is the domain of the e-mail account configured in step 5).

varlistentry.term: Can you reach the outgoing mail server?

listitem.para: Verify you can ping the mail server with ping -c 5 &mailname; (where &mailname; is the host name of the mail server returned by the host command in the previous step).

varlistentry.term: Does the test message still not arrive?

listitem.para: If mailq reports the message has been sent successfully, the problem must be on the receiving end. Check the configuration of the remote e-mail account and its spam folder.
